statement: The research plan addresses three important dimensions of generative model evaluation: quality, diversity, and distributional similarity.

The main weakness comes from evaluating the metrics in such a controlled and synthetic setting where quality metrics are evaluated on proteins which the underlying models (such as ESMFold) are trained on, making it unclear whether these metrics generalize to proteins they are not trained on.

It is not clear from the research plan whether these metrics correlate with anything experimentally, therefore the evaluation of these metrics in the given scenario doesn't seem to offer much practical insight on the usefulness of these metrics.

The research plan claims to evaluate protein generative models but proceeds to ignore protein structure generative models such as RFdiffusion and Chroma, only attempting to evaluate protein sequences without consideration for generated structures.

There are no benchmarks of actual generative models in the experimental design, with experiments conducted only on artificial perturbations of known sequences and on a curated set of sequences from 5 protein families.

The noise perturbations using random amino acid substitutions are artificial, and it is unclear if randomly mutating 5-30% of the sequence represents a failure mode or common occurrence in existing protein generative models.
Using only 5 protein families in the diversity assessment setup is far too small of an evaluation set.
The systematic perturbation of amino acid sequences is a good idea, but random noise with uniform transition probabilities is unrealistic compared to using BLOSUM or PAM matrices.

The random perturbations do not create meaningful biological diversity in the sequences and simply degrade their quality, raising questions about how the metrics behave for meaningful diverse sequences that were not generated with random noising.
